repnme.cdata!: Ghana - Private Sector Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project (PSAC) is rated
            satisfactory: it achieved its objectives. All the components
            were effectively implemented resulting in substantially
            reducing government ownership of commercial enterprises and
            in fiscal saving. Furthermore, the project signaled stronger
            government commitment to enhance the role of the private
            sector. Key lessons learned include emphasizing the need for
            quality privatizations. The implementing agency should
            ensure that the process is widely publicized so as to
            attract as many competitive bidders as possible. The
            selected buyers should be committed to returning the
            enterprises to viability. At the same time, the buyers
            should be capable and willing to meet their outstanding
            obligations. Compliance can be achieved by writing default
            clauses into the sales contracts and invoking these clauses
            when default occurs. Because the project assumed that
            process issues could be resolved in a shorter time and the
            outsourcing process was oversimplified, unforeseen delays
            occurred in implementing the divestiture program.
            Fundamental issues like the legalities involved in
            transferring land titles need to be addressed system-wide.
            Combining this project with the Public Enterprise and
            Privatization Technical Assistance Project (PEPTA) was
            helpful as the two projects were coordinated as one
            operation with some mutual conditionalities, which
            effectively meant more supervision time for the PSAC
            privatization component.

18157655.theme: State-owned enterprise restructuring and privatization,International financial standards and systems,Other public sector governance,Public expenditure, financial management and procurement,Macroeconomic management
18157655.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Economic management,Public sector governance

repnme.cdata!: Ghana - Private Sector Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Private Sector Adjustment Credit
            Project will provide balance of payments financing in
            support of the Government's program to promote private
            sector growth by accelerating the pace of privatization and
            by maintaining an appropriate macroeconomic policy
            framework, including improved management and
            poverty-orientation of public expenditures. The
            privatization component, which cuts across several sectors
            and uses private firms to implement privatization, has three
            parts: the first, covers 46 medium sized state-owned
            enterprises (SOEs); the second covers 64 small SOEs; and the
            third covers 4 large and strategic SOEs, including Ghana
            Telecom and State Insurance Corporation. Of these, the
            Government is expected to sell or liquidate 48 small and
            medium-sized SOEs and to offer for sale 3 large and
            strategic SOEs including Ghana Telecom, within the program
            period. The macroeconomic framework component, in addition
            to ensuring fiscal and monetary discipline, seeks to
            implement better expenditure monitoring systems in 16
            ministries covering at least 70 percent of total
            expenditures, a more efficient multi-year contracting system
            in 2 ministries, and a comprehensive accounting system in 6
            ministries. Also, expenditures on basic education, primary
            health, and rural infrastructure will be increased in real
            terms to improve the poor's human resources and
            income-augmenting opportunities.
